titleStmt.title: I go around
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was drafted during the time Whitman visited soldiers in the Washington hospitals, not before January 1863 and not after the end of the Civil War.
The manuscript leaf is mounted on a backing sheet, making the verso inaccessible.
The following are responsible for particular readings or for changes to this file, as noted: Elizabeth Lorang Ashley Lawson Tim Jackson

revisionDesc.change: added note about verso being inaccessible
corrected based on additional review by KP, BB, EL

body.p: I go around among these menamong these, sights, amongthesethe crowded hospitals doing what I can yet it is a mere drop in the bucket——I find many things are attended to, (after a fashion) but—still the work I try to do, and have at last found myself compelleddrawn into, is not thought path I follow, I suppose I may say, is my own. I go The soldiers are mostly Americans, and mostly young men,—— it is strange how affectionate and yet how brave they are —I never scease admiring & wondering at them—— they love to have some one to they endure many of them of course endure much agony—lying there, it is most pitiful—so good so handsomemanly, so friendless, so handsome lying there in their cots, I have the greatest comfort in ministering to them, especially to their thirst for gentlereal friendship
